Legislation or Policy Name: Building Bridges Initiative (BBI) / Constitution of Kenya (Amendment) Bill 2020
Judicial Status: Declared Unconstitutional (High Court, Court of Appeal, and Supreme Court)
Key Constitutional Issue: Basic Structure Doctrine; Sovereignty of the people; Separation of Powers; Presidential overreach in initiating a 'popular initiative' (Article 257); Fraud on the Constitution.
Executive Workaround (Inferred): Policy Laundering: Framing an executive project as a 'popular initiative' to bypass consensus; Shifted strategy to 'statutory expansion' (creating offices via ordinary Acts) or fragmented implementation via executive actions and budget allocations.

Legislation or Policy Name: Constituency Development Fund (CDF) / National Government Constituencies Development Fund (NG-CDF)
Key Constitutional Issue: Separation of Powers (Articles 1, 94, 95); Devolution (Chapter 11, Article 174); MPs performing executive functions; Public Finance Management.
Executive Workaround (Inferred): Legislative Ping-Pong: Repeated rebranding (CDF to NG-CDF) and cosmetic structural changes (e.g., naming MPs 'patrons') to appear compliant while maintaining control; currently seeking permanent constitutional entrenchment to render judicial review moot.
Current Status: High Court granted transition period until June 30, 2026; Parliament seeking constitutional amendment (Bill 2025).

Legislation or Policy Name: Affordable Housing Levy / Affordable Housing Act, 2024
Judicial Status: Declared Unconstitutional (High Court 2023); Challenge declared Moot (Supreme Court 2024)
Key Constitutional Issue: Discrimination (salaried vs. informal); Lack of legal framework; Right to Housing (Article 43); Violation of Public Participation (Article 118).
Executive Workaround (Inferred): Legislative Reincarnation: 'Move fast and legalize later'; rapidly enacting a standalone Act to cure procedural and discriminatory defects (expanding the tax base) to render ongoing litigation moot.
Current Status: Active; Re-implemented via Affordable Housing Act 2024.

Judicial Status: Declared Unconstitutional (High Court, Court of Appeal)
Key Constitutional Issue: Lack of Public Participation; Violation of Article 155 (duplication of Principal Secretary roles); Lack of statutory backing.
Executive Workaround (Inferred): Laundering appointments by treating judicial rulings as 'drafting instructions' to create the missing legal basis retroactively through statutory amendments (National Government Coordination Act).
Current Status: Appointments nullified; awaiting statutory backing via National Government Administration Laws (Amendment) Bill.

Judicial Status: Nullified by Court of Appeal; Reinstated by Supreme Court (Oct 2024)
Key Constitutional Issue: Public Participation (Article 118); Culture of Justification; Money Bill concurrence (Article 114); Accountability in feedback loops.
Executive Workaround (Inferred): Use of 'Omnibus Legislation' to restructure social contracts; immediate application for 'stay of execution' to continue implementation during appeals; migration of voided sections to standalone Acts.

Key Constitutional Issue: Right to Privacy (Article 31); Lack of Data Protection Impact Assessment (DPIA); Exclusion of marginalized groups; Insufficient Public Participation.
Executive Workaround (Inferred): Fait Accompli Strategy: Rapid, irreversible implementation; rebranding (Huduma to Maisha); using secondary regulations to bypass parliamentary scrutiny; expediting the Data Protection Act 2019 solely to satisfy judicial requirements.
Current Status: Maisha Namba rollout continuing despite injunctions; Huduma Namba operational following Data Protection Act.

Key Constitutional Issue: Media Freedom (Article 34); Freedom of Expression (Article 33); Judicial oversight; Proportionality test (Article 24).
Executive Workaround (Inferred): Logrolling: Smuggling controversial provisions into an 'Omnibus' bill during national crises to overwhelm oversight; reintroducing struck-down 'false publication' clauses in subsequent cybercrime laws ('Zombie Laws').
Current Status: Partially invalidated; specific sections struck down.

Judicial Status: Suspended by High Court (120-day window); Stayed by Court of Appeal
Key Constitutional Issue: Right to Health (Article 43 - denial of emergency care); Right to Privacy (Article 31 - digital data collection); Lack of meaningful Public Participation.
Executive Workaround (Inferred): Invoking the 'Doctrine of Necessity' in the Court of Appeal to avoid a legal vacuum, allowing implementation of a flawed system to prevent administrative collapse following the repeal of NHIF.
Current Status: Operating under a stay of execution granted by the Court of Appeal.

Legislation or Policy Name: Computer Misuse and Cybercrimes Act (CMCA) 2018 / 2024 Amendment
Judicial Status: Initially suspended; later Upheld (2018). 2024 Bill pending.
Key Constitutional Issue: Freedom of Expression (Article 33); Right to Privacy; Freedom of Conscience (Article 32); Public Participation; Vague definitions of 'fake news'.
Executive Workaround (Inferred): Zombie Legislation: Re-enacting unconstitutional clauses previously struck down in security acts by renaming and embedding them in digital-focused statutes.
Current Status: 2018 Act Validated; 2024 Amendment Bill approved by Committee with amendments.

Key Constitutional Issue: Sovereign Power (Article 1); Public Participation; Right to life and assembly.
Executive Workaround (Inferred): President utilized powers under Article 115(1)(b) to refer the bill back to Parliament with a memorandum recommending deletion of all clauses to defuse civil unrest.
Strategic Inaction: Intentional indifference and judicial non-enforcement used to maintain current power structures despite multiple court orders.

Key Constitutional Issue: Chapter Six (Leadership and Integrity); Independent Oversight.
Executive Workaround (Inferred): Regulatory Sabotage: Mutilation of the Bill by the Legislature to exclude relatives from definitions and shift wealth oversight from EACC to the Parliamentary Service Commission.

Judicial Status: Constitutionality challenged in Court of Appeal
Key Constitutional Issue: Equality and freedom from discrimination (Article 27); Right to property (Article 40).
Executive Workaround (Inferred): The Legislature maintains laws requiring proof of contribution, effectively disadvantaging women despite constitutional guarantees of equal rights.

Legislation or Policy Name: Employment and Labour Relations policies (Sexual Harassment)
Key Constitutional Issue: Human dignity (Article 28); Freedom and security of the person (Article 29); Labour relations (Article 41).
Executive Workaround (Inferred): Failure to implement robust internal redress mechanisms, requiring judicial intervention to enforce constitutional standards.

Legislation or Policy Name: Local Transit Safety and Mobility Regulations
Key Constitutional Issue: Freedom of movement (Article 39); Freedom and security of the person (Article 29).
Executive Workaround (Inferred): Regulatory gaps in the public transport sector (Saccos) shift the burden of enforcement to individual litigants and human rights initiatives.

Key Constitutional Issue: National police service structure and oversight.
Executive Workaround (Inferred): Administrative restructuring and presidential directives used to implement reforms without legislative approval to bypass failed bills.
Shifting licensing authorities or using tax measures to achieve regulatory goals without passing new substantive laws.
